title: 109_hr5211
content: The Act may be cited as the "Senior Citizen's Improved Quality of Life Act" and includes provisions for the preservation of Social Security. The Senior Citizen's Improved Quality of Life Act includes amendments to the Social Security Act regarding the investment of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The Managing Trustee is responsible for determining the annual surplus for each Trust Fund and ensuring it is invested in the following fiscal year. The annual surplus of the Trust Funds is invested in marketable interest-bearing obligations of the United States or certificates of deposit in insured depository institutions. The excess of amounts appropriated to the Trust Funds determines the annual surplus for each Trust Fund at the end of a fiscal year. The Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund receives appropriations under specific subsections for each fiscal year, along with amounts credited under the Social Security Amendments of 1983. These appropriations are compared to the amounts paid out during the fiscal year. The amendments made by this subsection apply to annual surpluses starting from fiscal years after October 1, 2005. Protection of the Social Security Trust Funds from the Public Debt Limit ensures timely deposits and investments in trust funds without deviation from normal procedures. Protection of the Social Security Trust Funds from the Public Debt Limit ensures timely deposits and investments in trust funds without deviation from normal procedures. No officer or employee of the United States may disinvest amounts in Trust Funds invested in public debt obligations to reduce outstanding public debt obligations. During any period where cash benefits or administrative expenses would not be payable from the Trust Funds, certain protections are in place. The Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund or the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund may sell or redeem public debt obligations only when cash assets are not available for benefit payments or administrative expenses. Corresponding debt may be issued for this purpose. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue public debt obligations to obtain cash for benefit payments or administrative expenses from the Insurance Trust Fund, bypassing the public debt limit. Advance notice must be given to Congress and the Comptroller General before any sale or redemption authorized under this provision. The Comptroller General reviews compliance with the issuance of public debt obligations and provides findings and recommendations to Congress. Public debt obligations refer to obligations subject to the public debt limit. SEC. 3. SOCIAL SECURITY FOR AMERICANS ONLY. The amendment to Section 215(e) of the Social Security Act limits coverage for individuals not citizens or nationals of the United States in computing their earnings for Social Security benefits. The amendment to Section 233 of the Social Security Act revises the authorization for totalization agreements for individuals not citizens or nationals of the United States. The amendment to Section 233 of the Social Security Act revises the authorization for totalization agreements for individuals not citizens or nationals of the United States, focusing on international agreements. The President is authorized to enter agreements with foreign countries to resolve social security entitlement questions. Agreements must consider wage and income crediting limitations. The amendment applies to agreements after the enactment date, including existing agreements under Section 233 of the Social Security Act. The agreement under section 233 of the Social Security Act will end on December 31, 2006 or earlier as specified in the agreement. SEC. 4. SENIORS' HEALTH CARE FREEDOM. Amends Section 1802(b) of the Social Security Act to facilitate private contracts under Medicare. No eligibility condition based on refusal to participate in a government program. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF INCLUSION IN GROSS INCOME OF SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to terminate the application of section 86 for taxable years after the enactment date. Appropriations are made to Social Security and Railroad Retirement funds to offset reductions in transfers due to this amendment, with a stipulation that tax increases will not be used for this purpose. SEC. 6. INCOME TAX CREDIT FOR PRESCRIPTION DRUGS PURCHASED BY INDIVIDUALS WHO HAVE ATTAINED RETIREMENT AGE. This section introduces a new tax credit for prescription drugs purchased by individuals who have reached Social Security retirement age. Individuals who have reached social security retirement age can receive a tax credit equal to 80% of the amount paid for prescribed drugs during the taxable year. The credit is coordinated with the medical expense deduction to avoid double benefits. The tax credit for prescribed drugs is not allowed for amounts paid from Archer MSA or health savings accounts. Taxpayers can elect not to have the credit apply for a taxable year. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning more than 1 year after the enactment of this Act. Facilitation of importation of FDA-approved drugs and internet sales of prescription drugs is addressed in Section 7. The amendment allows for the importation of FDA-approved drugs by qualified importers upon approval by the Secretary. The amendment allows for the importation of FDA-approved drugs by qualified importers upon approval by the Secretary. Drugs subject to section 503(b)(1) or containing insulin must meet all requirements for admission into the United States, including approval under section 505 or 351 of the Public Health Service Act, and must not be adulterated or misbranded. The Secretary must approve or refuse an application within 60 days, providing reasons for refusal. The amendment allows for the importation of FDA-approved drugs by qualified importers upon approval by the Secretary. The Secretary must approve or refuse an application within 60 days, providing reasons for refusal. Internet sales of prescription drugs are also addressed, stating that the Secretary may not take action against those involved in the sale if certain conditions are met. The amendment allows for the importation of FDA-approved drugs by qualified importers upon approval by the Secretary. Internet sales of prescription drugs are addressed, stating that the sale is considered interstate if conducted through an Internet site and introducing the drug into interstate commerce. The Secretary is not authorized to enforce any violation of State law in this regard. The amendment allows for importation of FDA-approved drugs by qualified importers upon approval by the Secretary. Regulations must be promulgated by the Secretary of Health and Human Services before the specified period to carry out the amendments to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. The regulations required by the amendment to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act take effect one year after the enactment of the Act, regardless of whether they have been promulgated.
